Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Modeling Platform Competition: A Multi-Agent Systems Approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
In many important real-world settings, the interactions of multiple agents are governed by the platform that brings them together. Even if we assume rational behavior on the parts of agents, the outcomes of such interactions depend heavily on the rules, regulations, and norms of the platform. When multiple such platforms compete in dynamic environments, and agents are constrained in terms of their knowledge and computational capabilities, it becomes very difficult to predict societal outcomes based only on traditional economic theory. The goal of this project is to employ computational methods to study platform competition in three important domains: (1) financial markets; (2) kidney exchange; (3) online episodic labor and matching markets. We will explore these domains in detail, focusing initially on the following questions: (1) In financial markets, is high-frequency trading (HFT) beneficial or costly to society? If it is costly, how can we incentivize agents to switch to market platforms that do away with the incentives for HFT? (2) When multiple living-donor paired kidney exchanges compete on how frequently they run their matching algorithms, is this socially harmful in preventing a thicker market that would potentially allow more matches? Does this disproportionately affect certain types of patients? If so, how can we incentivize exchanges or patients to wait longer? (3) In platforms that allow users to search for tangible goods/durables (e.g. cars) or intangible matches, how does the amount and type of information provided to participants affect social welfare? How do the dynamics of platform competition affect the information available to users?

In this project, the PI and his students will use multiple approaches, including computational game theory, multi-agent simulation, and empirical game analysis, to model the dynamics of platform competition. Applying the computational lens to studying the dynamics of platform competition is particularly important because of three features of these environments: (1) The complex interactions that occur between participants (e.g. traders learning from market prices, platforms deciding how much information to provide to participants); (2) The inherent complexity of the decision-problems faced by the big players (the platform itself, or agents that perform an important service for the platform) like market-makers in financial markets or the clearing algorithm for kidney exchanges; (3) A focus on the dynamics of how platforms evolve under competition. This research program will serve to both elucidate important questions about the specific applications, as well as explore new methodological questions as they arise in how computational modeling of economic and social systems can contribute deeper understanding when used in conjunction with the types of modeling common to economics and operations research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project employed computational methods to study platform competition in financial markets and living-donor organ transplantation. We developed new models that used computational techniques and the "algorithmic lens" to understand the effects of competition between platforms, especially in settings where individuals may be able to attempt to transact on multiple platforms simultaneously (for example, patients being listed for transplant on two exchanges, or traders putting orders onto two exchanges and then canceling those that do not execute first).

Our investigations revealed many interesting results, published in a series of papers at venues including ACM EC, AAAI, IJCAI, AAMAS, and NeurIPS. We highlight a few here. One of the most compelling insights was that there is a social cost of a "race to the bottom" phenomenon that occurs in many of these settings. For example, in both financial markets and matching markets like kidney exchange, it is typically in the interest of platforms to compete on immediacy, by executing transactions (whether a financial trade or a proposed transplant) more and more rapidly. In such cases, individuals will, of course, accept the immediate transaction, but this results in thinner markets with worse outcomes for individuals and the population in expectation (see citations [1-3] below). 

This project also supported work in understanding trading dynamics and pricing in markets [4,5] and helped initiate new lines of work in our group around using quantifications of match quality in order to incorporate cardinal utilities into matching models [6], and around the computational consideration of information design in markets as a complement to mechanism design [7,8].
The project supported the training of several graduate and undergraduate students. Three Ph.D. students (Mithun Chakraborty, Zhuoshu Li, and Hao Yan) worked on this project at different times; they all successfully defended their dissertations and found positions in academia or industry. Several undergraduate students worked on projects that were directly related to this work, and many of them are now in Ph.D. programs, for example at Cornell, Duke, and UT Austin. The project also enabled new collaborations that we expect will continue for a long time, especially with John Dickerson at the University of Maryland, and Jason Wellen at the Washington University School of Medicine.

We disseminated the results of our research broadly in both the academic and non-academic communities, including through conference presentations at the conferences mentioned above, invited talks at universities and companies, practitioner conferences, and tutorials at conferences including INFORMS and AAMAS.

Chakraborty and Das, NeurIPS 2015[5] "Trading On A Rigged Game: Outcome Manipulation In Prediction Markets."
